newsitem.title: CHINA: Australia sees booming Chinese tourist market.
newsitem.headline: Australia sees booming Chinese tourist market.

text.p: The Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) is planning to open an office in China this year amid rapid growth in the numbers of Asian travellers to Australia, the commission said on Monday.
Nearly 54,000 mainland Chinese visited Australia in 1996, a 26.7 percent increase from the year before, with visitors spending an average of A$3,968 (US$3,056) per visit, it said in a statement.
The numbers of visitors from Asia was expected to double by the year 2001 to 2.4 million, the statement quoted John Morse, the commission's managing director, as saying.
"In recognition of the importance of this region and the long-term potential of the China market, the ATC plans to open an office in China later this year," Morse said.
The office would likely be in Shanghai, he said but gave no timetable for the office's inauguration.
As many as 600,000 Chinese from the mainland and Hong Kong would visit Australia every year by 2001, making it one of the country's major source markets, he said.
Some 153,000 Hong Kong residents made trips to Australia in 1996, a rise of 16.3 percent from the year before, the commission said.
